questions.question_text: Which role(s) are required to impersonate a user? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
CE - as per the book. 
A - you could impersonate a user with the security_admin role, but it is not required, you can do that with the normal admin.
CE are correct

Selected Answer: CE
sys_user is a table, there is no such thing as sys_admin in SNOW, 
the correct answers are C - Impersonator so you can impersonate people if you are not admin and admin - if you are system administrator and you can 
impersonate people as a sys admin.

Selected Answer: CE
C and E. No sys_admin role in ServiceNow
I see this as C and E as per current info.

Selected Answer: CE
CE is for me

Selected Answer: BD
B and D is correct

Selected Answer: B
B is the right one

Selected Answer: B
You have a spreadsheet:
1) You need to Load it
2) Create Transform map based on data
3) Run transformation

I believe the answer is D
1. Select your import set (create new or select existing table)
2. Create new or use existing transform map
3. Run the transform

questions.question_text: Which set of steps is used to import spreadsheet data into a ServiceNow table?

choices.C: Define Data Source, Select Transform Map, Run Transform
choices.D: Select Import Set, Select Transform Map, Run Transform
choices.B: Load Data, Create Transform Map, Run Transform

questions.question_text: An administrator creates “customer_table_admin” and “customer_table_user” roles for the newly created "Customer Table”. Which ACL rule would grant access to all rows and all fields to both the customer_table_admin and customer_table_user roles?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
additional reference in ServiceNow Administrator Fundamentals eBook Page 60
The None access Control (which appears as just sys_user) granted all rows and all fields to both the table_admin and table_user roles.

Selected Answer: A
Best Practice:
- when creating .* Access Controls, also create a None Access Control, because only None grants access to records
- when writing an ACL that mostly grants access, use only None
- when writing an ACL that mostly denies access, use None and .*

Completely agree with kanafuka225. The table.* is allowing access to both of these new roles to all rows and fields as specified. Conversely, table.none is restricting all row and field access to these two roles.

Selected Answer: A
none will be used to grant all accesses to the record

Selected Answer: A
.none is the table level which grants access to all fields and rows.

Selected Answer: D
The customer .* ACL rule would grant access to all rows and all fields to both the customer_table_admin and customer_table_user roles because it uses a wildcard (*) to match any operation on the customer table. The other options are either too restrictive or too broad.
References1: Access control list rules - Product Documentation: Utah - ServiceNow4: Access Controls - ServiceNow Elite

Selected Answer: ACE
A,C,E is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: ACE
A,C,E is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: ACE
user,incident,task
